TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine-loamy, mixed, frigid Aridic Durixerolls

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Nark gravelly loam - rangeland (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
A1--0 to 2 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) gravelly loam, very dark grayish brown (10YR 3/2) moist; massive; soft, very friable, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; root crowns only; many very fine and fine interstitial pores; 25 percent pebbles; mildly alkaline (pH 7.4); abrupt smooth boundary. (l to 4 inches thick)
Bt1--2 to 6 inches; grayish brown (10YR 5/2) gravelly clay loam, dark brown (10YR 3/3) moist; moderate fine angular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, sticky, plastic; common very fine roots many very fine and fine interstitial pores; 30 percent pebbles; common thin clay films as bridges, and few very thin clay films on peds; moderately alkaline (pH 8.2); abrupt smooth boundary. (2 to 6 inches thick)
Bt2--6 to 10 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) gravelly clay loam, brown (10YR 4/3) moist; moderate fine angular blocky structure; hard, friable, sticky, plastic; common very fine and few fine roots; many very fine and fine interstitial pores; 25 percent pebbles; common thin clay films as bridges; moderately alkaline (pH 8.4); abrupt smooth boundary. (2 to 8 inches thick)
Btk3--10 to 14 inches; very pale brown (10YR 7/3) gravelly loam, brown (10YR 5/3) moist; strong fine angular blocky structure; very hard, firm, sticky, plastic; common very fine and few fine roots; many very fine and fine interstitial pores; 25 percent pebbles; few thin clay films as bridges and coats; strongly effervescent; strongly alkaline (pH 8.6); abrupt wavy boundary. (2 to 4 inches thick)
Bqk1--14 to 23 inches; white (10YR 8/2) loam, pale brown (10YR 6/3) moist; strong fine subangular blocky structure; very hard, firm, slightly sticky, slightly plastic; common very fine roots common fine and medium interstitial pores; 70 percent silica and lime cemented durinodes; violently effervescent; strongly alkaline (pH 8.8); abrupt wavy boundary. (4 to 10 inches thick)
Bqk2--23 to 35 inches; white (10YR 8/1 and 8/2) sandy loam, very pale brown (10YR 7/3) moist; massive; very hard, firm, nonsticky, nonplastic; few very fine roots; common fine and medium interstitial pores; weakly cemented; violently effervescent; strongly alkaline (pH 8.8); abrupt wavy boundary. (10 to 16 inches thick)
Bqkm--35 to 40 inches; white (10YR 8/1) indurated duripan, very pale brown (10YR 7/3) moist; massive; extremely hard, extremely firm, violently effervescent.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION: White Pine County, Nevada; about 3 miles southwest of Mt. Hamilton; about 1,800 feet south and 1,800 feet west of the northeast corner of sec. 25, T.16N., R.56E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content: RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS: The solum is 10 to 19 inches thick and the depth to the indurated duripan is 24 to 38 inches. The mollic epipedon is 7 to 10 inches thick. These soils are usually dry, mainly during the summer and autumn. The mean annual soil temperature is 45 to 47 degrees F., and the mean summer soil temperature is 61 to 63 degrees F. The A1 horizon has value of 5 or 6 dry, and chroma of 2 or 3. When the surface 7 inches are mixed, value is less than 5.5 dry. It has weak or moderate very fine granular structure, or it is massive. This horizon is soft or slightly hard. The Bt1 horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 5 through 7 dry, 3 through 5 moist, and chroma of 2 through 4. It is dominantly clay loam but subhorizons of some pedons are gravelly loam. This horizon averages 27 to 35 percent clay and 15 to 35 percent pebbles. It has moderate or strong angular blocky or weak prismatic structure. The Bqk2 horizon immediately above the indurated duripan has 3 to 6 inches of strongly cemented material in some pedons. The duripan (Bqkm horizon) has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 6 through 8 dry, 5 through 7 moist, and chroma of 1 through 4.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES: These are the Hecki and Nevu series. Hecki soils have bedrock within depth of 40 inches. Nevu soils are calcareous except in the immediate surface 2 to 4 inches, have solum thickness of 20 to 27 inches and have mollic epipedons 10 to 18 inches thick.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING: Nark soils are on smooth or slightly convex, nearly level to moderately sloping old alluvial fan piedmonts at elevations of 6,300 to 7,000 feet. Slope gradients are O to 8 percent. The soils formed in mixed alluvium mainly from sedimentary rock sources and include limestone and shale. The climate is cool, continental with an average precipitation of 10 to 12 inches. The mean annual temperature is 43 to 45 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS: These are the Belmill and Lien soils. Belmill soils lack duripans. Lien soils have loamy-skeletal control sections.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY: Well drained; medium runoff; moderately slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION: Used for grazing by livestock and wildlife. The vegetation is principally big sagebrush, rabbitbrush, needle-and-thread grass, Great Basin wildrye, Indian ricegrass, and scattered juniper.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT: Nark soils are in the southwestern part of White Pine County, Nevada and are inextensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE:  Davis, California.

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED: BLM Duckwater Planning Unit, Nevada, 1974.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  The OSED was scanned by NSSQA in 1987.  Content was last revised by the state on 1/74.
Nark soils were originally classified as Calcisols.
The taxonomic classification was changed in 1990 from Fine, montmorillonitic, frigid Xerollic Durargids to Fine-loamy, mixed, frigid Aridic Durixerolls.
The series was inactivated in 4/2001 as it was never formally correlated in the soil survey of Western White Pine County Area, Nevada.  The type location was mapped over with other soil series that have similar use and management.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
